title: Discussion and Transparency
abstract: This section provides a transparent summary of the framework's inputs, compares it to other theoretical approaches, discusses supersymmetry, inflation, and black hole information, and outlines limitations and future work.

contentBlocks.text: Unlike string landscape approaches with 10^500 vacua, this framework selects a single TCS G2 manifold through topological constraints. The generation count n_gen = 3 emerges uniquely, not as a statistical accident.
The PM framework is compatible with slow-roll inflation through the attractor scalar phi_M.

contentBlocks.text: The framework is explicitly non-supersymmetric at low energies, consistent with the experimental absence of superpartners at the LHC. This is not a deficiency but a structural feature.

contentBlocks.title: SUSY in PM: Emergent and High-Scale Broken
content: Chiral fermions from topology: Three generations arise from G2 index theorems (n_gen = |chi(Y)|/2), not from supersymmetric matter multiplets
No low-energy SUSY required: The G2 compactification produces Standard Model matter content directly; supersymmetry is not invoked for hierarchy protection
UV completion: If supersymmetry exists in the UV (e.g., via 11D supergravity lift), it is broken at the compactification scale by flux and moduli stabilization
Superpartner bounds: Any superpartners would appear at or above M_GUT ~ 2.1 x 10^16 GeV - beyond all foreseeable experimental reach

contentBlocks.text: LHC Consistency: Current exclusion limits place squarks and gluinos above ~2 TeV. The PM framework predicts superpartners (if any) at ~10^16 GeV - a factor of 10^13 above current bounds. The LHC null results are therefore a prediction of this framework, not a puzzle.

contentBlocks.text: This framework derives Standard Model parameters from a single TCS G2 manifold with 1 constraint (Higgs mass fixes Re(T)). The agreement with experimental data should be interpreted with caution: while many predictions fall within experimental uncertainties, the framework remains a theoretical proposal requiring experimental validation.

The framework makes testable predictions: normal neutrino hierarchy, KK graviton signatures near 5 TeV, and specific dark energy evolution. Confirmation or refutation of these predictions by DUNE, HL-LHC, and next-generation cosmology surveys will provide meaningful tests.
